title: 113_hr3357
content:
The "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" aims to assist States in enhancing the knowledge, credentials, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators in early childhood education programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "early childhood education program" includes Head Start Program, State-funded prekindergarten program, licensed child care for prekindergarten children, and special education preschool. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965.

SEC. 4. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Secretary of Education, with input from the Secretary of Health and Human Services, can grant funds to States for implementing activities outlined in section 6. Applications for grants are authorized. Each State seeking a grant under this Act must submit an application to the Secretary of Education, including details of their early childhood professional development system developed in collaboration with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care. The State agency responsible for administering childcare, the State Head Start collaboration director, the State educational agency, institutions of higher education, organizations representing early childhood educators, and credible early childhood education professional organizations are designated in section 642B of the Head Start Act. The State must also designate an agency to administer the grant program and describe how the State's system provides oversight, professional standards, competencies, and a career lattice. The curr_chunk discusses the coordination with State higher education agencies, accrediting bodies, and institutions to encourage articulation agreements and offer more accessible higher education for working learners. The curr_chunk focuses on providing support to adult learners, particularly those who are dual language learners or come from low-income or minority communities. It also emphasizes the use of workforce data to assess the State's workforce needs and discusses the financing of these initiatives over time. The curr_chunk focuses on the state's use of funds for supporting adult learners, especially those from low-income or minority communities. It also highlights the importance of using workforce data to assess the state's workforce needs and discusses the financing of these initiatives over time. A State receiving a grant under this Act must use the funds for scholarships covering tuition, fees, materials, transportation, and release time for preschool teachers pursuing a bachelor's degree in early childhood education. Additionally, funds can support preschool teachers with a bachelor's degree in a different field to obtain credentials or licensure in early childhood education. To increase compensation for teachers enrolled in early childhood education programs and provide ongoing professional development opportunities addressing all areas of child development and learning. The curr_chunk focuses on areas of child development and learning, teacher-child interaction, family engagement, and cultural competence for working with diverse children and families. The Act emphasizes that grant funds should supplement, not replace, other available federal, state, and local funds for early childhood educator preparation. States receiving funds must maintain or increase their fiscal effort for supported activities. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
